characters: A SERIES OF SHOTS THAT FADE INTO EACH OTHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sweet silence of slumber. Suddenly, an alarm clock on nightstand SHRIEKS the operatic tones of Maria Callas. A well-manicured hand, nails painted pink, slaps the snoo button and mutes Maria. A few seconds reprieve. Then, another clock, stationed on a dresser, broadcasts t FORTISSIMO POUNDING of the "William Tell Overture." Toes, also painted pink, swing out of bed and run to the dresse LETTY MAYER, late 20s and beautiful, turns off the music. She opens a dresser drawer and surveys panties that are arranged by color, from white to beige to black. Behind t panties are rows of bras, also organized by color. Letty pulls out some taupe undergarments, checks them against h nails and replaces them in favor of a pink bra and pantie Letty goes to her closet and removes a tailored, pink lin suit. She lays it on the bed. Beast, her cat, jumps on th bed and settles into the jacket. Letty swoops the animal her clothes and brushes cat hair from the suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Beast. What have I told you about linen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scolding is cut short by an "Urge Overkill" song that SCREAMS OUT from another room. On cue, Letty heads down t hall, dressing as she goes. She CLUCKS for Beast to follo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty turns off the alarm clock that BLASTS "Urge Overkil from the counter and checks the time against her watch. She swings open a cupboard to look at cans of cat food arranged by type. Seafood on the left, chicken in the middle, then, naturally, beef. Letty reaches for a can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Beast) It's liver saute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty considers the cat a moment, and chooses another can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, then, chicken in gravy. But you're going to have to eat the liver tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty puts the finishing touches on her make-up and pulls back her hair, plastering an errant curl into place with spray. Yet another alarm clock sounds, this time BLARING voice of shock jocks MARK AND BRIAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty hurries down the hall and turns off the clock, whic mounted near the front door. She bends down to kiss the c good-bye, grabs a briefcase and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A school bell BUZZES. Grade-schoolers, clutching lunch pails, scurry past Letty, who stands outside an office do She straightens her jacket, takes a deep breath and start turn the handle. Letty is stopped cold when CHANDRA, 7, the victim of a bl nose, runs up to her, bawling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayer. Miss Mayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty looks quickly at Chandra, her watch, the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chandra) Goodness, this is a bad one.   Tip your head back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bends down and pushes back Chandra's head. Chandra, o balance, places one very bloody hand on Letty's jacket la staining it for all eternity. Letty, grimacing, takes the bloody hand firmly in her own guides Chandra down the hall, coaxing the child as she go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Pinch it, Chandra. Pinch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCIPAL GAIL LAUER, 40s, sits in uncomfortable silence BILL JOHANSEN, the 50-something school Superintendent. Al present are MRS. MONTES, who is a School Board Member, an two other BOARD MEMBERS. Principal Gail glances at the clock. Mrs. Montes taps her foot. Johansen clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have a full calendar today, and I'm afraid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bursts open. Letty stumbles into the room. She clutches her briefcase to her chest, trying to cover her blood-smeared lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johansen, hello. I'm so sorry I'm late. It's very nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty continues to hug the briefcase while awkwardly bend down to shake hands with Johansen and the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Superintendent was just getting ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do apologize.    A student had a crisis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crisis, you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bloody nose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no response. Letty reluctantly lowers the briefc and reveals the stain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bloody nose of epic proportions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johansen smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, Miss Mayer. Ten minutes.     Wow us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of BOYS play kickball in a haze of sawdust. Chand sits on a bench, clamping an ice pack to her nose. JENNY, limber 8-year-old, hangs upside down from the jungle gym. Letty talks on her CELL PHONE. She glances around to moni her wards, eyes darting like a hawk's toward the kickball game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cherry drops, Jenny. (into the phone) Yes, hi. I'm calling for Paul Lascher. (beat) Could you tell him it's Letty? (beat) He can't? Um, well, tell him, tell him that they went for my math idea. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty dials again. She sees two boys fighting over the ba and moves in to break them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to boys) Not so rough, guys. (into phone) Mom? Hi. You'll never guess what...I've got the best news. (beat) No, about work. How about dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brawl averted, out of the corner of her eye, Letty catche Jenny make the daring Cherry Drop back flip off the bar. blows a series of ANGRY, STACCATO NOTES on her whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jenny) You're in trouble, young lady. (into the phone) I know, Mom. But it's the only place I can call from. (beat) Can you tell Ruth about dinner? (beat) Paul's fine, just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class bell BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to go, Mom.   The monsters call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuxedoed waiters glide through the tony restaurant, where patrons dare speak only in hushed tones. Letty sits sippi wine with her mother, MRS. MARTHA MAYER, immaculate in a cream suit, young looking for her 50-odd years. Letty's sister RUTH--early 20s and pretty, with flyaway h and an ever-present smile--bounds into the restaurant, oo happiness. Letty discretely waves her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pours her a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty was just getting ready to tell me her good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Letty) Tell, tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning toward Letty) Letty, dear, is that a cat hair on your blouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty removes the nasty hair from her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I got the district to approve my after-school math program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth smiles at her, but vacantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How wonderful, darling. (beat) What does that mean for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be running it three days a week, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you get time off to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, but maybe later, if they like the program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth stares around the restaurant, a shit-eating grin plastered across her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruth) What's up with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Nothing. Tell me more about the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruth) Not a job, a promotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mom, it's more of a prestige thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty passes her hand in front of Ruth's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth.   Calling Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go ahead and tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruth) Are you sure, Dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really. Tell me about the promotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my theory is that people can really enjoy math, but they lose interest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth can't hold it a moment longer without bursting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost screaming) I'm getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mayer's eyes immediately fill with tears. Ruth leaps and hugs her mother. Other diners glance toward the table One WOMAN IN THE RESTAURANT taps the side of her glass wi her fork and raises a silent toast to Ruth. Other DINERS follow suit. Ruth grins back and starts to giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy for you.     It's just wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mayer dabs her eyes with her napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness. A wedding.      My goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.   Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth dashes around the table to embrace the stunned Letty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Letty) Can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth sits back down and pulls a gorgeous ring from her pu She slips it on and wiggles her finger in front of Letty her mother, who peers at it with approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us every detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've only known Jake a few months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three and a week. (screaming again) Isn't it great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness. What about an engagement party? We must start planning. (signaling a waiter) Champagne. Girls, we need some champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Letty's frozen smile, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty's in bed, drawing a giant multiplication chart. PAU LASCHER, early 30s, handsome in a corporate way, shrugs o his expensive suit. He opens a drawer of Letty's dresser, and removes a neatl pressed T-shirt. He smooths out another shirt he has accidently rumpled in the process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, another one bites the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not another one. It's my sister. (beat) Aren't you happy for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's only known the guy a few months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul lays his folded trousers across Letty's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I put these here for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the closet) In there's better. (beat) It's kind of romantic, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really think if you're going to spend your life with someone you want to know them pretty damn well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits on the bed, and leans against a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I know your feelings on the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The receptionist said you called earlier about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty holds up her multiplication chart and shows it to P

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My math program. The Superintendent said he'd fund it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good going. I knew you could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul kisses Letty on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like we're both bucking for advancement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huntley told me today that if I come through on the Benton deposition, they may consider me for senior associate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty hugs Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.    We should celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking dinner on Friday with James and Meg at the Saint Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty sensually caresses his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like right now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I need to review the deposition questions tonight. Maybe tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ok.   Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought if you don't mind, you could listen and see how I come across?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Sure. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty continues coloring her multiplication chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty, please, I need your full attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty puts the chart down and sits up straighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty rubs her eyes with fatigue.    Bobby stands next to holding a crumpled paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dog ate my turtle, and the shell went crunch. I brought it for show- and-tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children perk up at this news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your turtle Bobby, but you know we only have show-and- tell on Mondays. Today, we're scheduled for grammar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my mom says I have to throw it away tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby opens the bag. He reaches in to remove the turtle. children TITTER. Letty's on him in a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs the bag. From outside, there is a KNOCK.     Le and the students look toward the window. It's Ruth. She's been crying.   She waves to Letty.    Ch waves back at Ruth. Letty puts up her finger to signal "just a minute" to Rut She sets the turtle bag on Bobby's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Class, why don't you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth knocks on the glass again. Letty glances at her distraught sister and walks quickly toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to class) You guys pull out your verb sheets and review them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty leaves the room. The class watches through the wind as Ruth throws her sobbing self into Letty's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she won't even come if Dad brings Monica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom won't miss your wedding. She'll come around. I promise she will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty glances through the window at her classroom, where Bobby waves the turtle over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to her, and to Dad, too. (beat) A few wisely-chosen guilt tactics and they'll be ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if we had them both to dinner or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty looks again at the classroom, where the students ar lobbing the turtle back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always throw the best dinner parties, Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty's attention snaps back to Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wait a minute, now I see where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad? At dinner together? Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth starts to sob--big, loud, air-gulping sobs.   Letty her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, though. Maybe it would work. I could throw you an engagement party maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Principal Gail, trolling the halls, spies Letty with Ruth She dispatches a stern look in Letty's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding toward Gail) You know what, Ruthie? I better get back to my class, OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it'll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth grabs Letty in another hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty strides into the classroom, pulls the turtle away f Bobby and drops it in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can come up here and give me a sentence with a "to be" verb in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on up, Zach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zach approaches the board and begins to write, "I am..." doesn't get any further before Letty cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neater, Zach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zach begins again, but Letty stops him when he reaches "a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zach, you know the line by the "a" has to come straight down or it looks like an "o."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zach looks back toward his classmates for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Zach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty picks up a piece of chalk and writes an "a." She erases it furiously and works at it until the "a" is perf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again, Zach.    Like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty jabs at the board with a piece of chalk. Zach freez He sees Letty's shoes, her arm, her contorted face, and, above all else, that perfect "a" staring right back down him. Letty grips Zach's arm, guiding the chalk to form what lo like a pretty good "a."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.    You still can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, OK, Miss Mayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not OK. You'll never get to college on OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty's fingers press into Zach's arm. A tear slides ominously down his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to be good, Zach.   Do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zach wrests free of Letty. He's in full cry now. He backs away, stumbles, then makes a run for his seat. Bobby SNICKERS at Zach's misfortune. Other children glance arou unsure, confused. Letty looks vacantly at the children, stares at the board looks at the children again. She sits down at her desk and buries her face in her hand Letty's fists, clenched at first, slowly relax. She takes deep breath and raises her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very, very sorry, Zach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zach continues to cry. Letty looks down at her desk. She grabs a piece of construction paper and a jar of paste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, guys? Wednesday's not a grammar day. It's a collage day. It's a collage ON THE WALL day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty jumps up. She slaps the paper on the wall with some paste. She motions for the students to join her. The children slowly approach her. Zach lags behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, Zach? Zach, I want you to be in charge of paste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty lies in bed. The alarm clock BLASTS opera. Letty fumbles for the switch. She can't turn it off. She yanks out the cord. Letty gets out of bed, walks to the dresser and turns off second clock before it rings. She goes to the KITCHEN and snaps off the alarm, then heads down the HALLWAY and shut that alarm off, as well. Letty hurries back to her BEDROOM and crawls into bed. toweling his hair dry, walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?    You're going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling in sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits on the bed and puts his hand to Letty's forehea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel like going to work today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't it be hard for them to get a substitute this late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about that math project?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, I just can't go. Is that OK with you or am I committing some horrible crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget I asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (beat) I'm just...I'm so tired lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you ought to see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just I've got those parent conferences, and I'm supposed to set up the math program by next week. And shopping for Ruth's dress and that, that engagement dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can get out of the dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't. I've already convinced both Mom and Dad to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Letty.   It'll get done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul touches Letty's shoulder. She pulls away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it will. Remember the big talent show you planned last year? And what about the Christmas benefit when Santa canceled at the last minute? But you still pulled it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just need to get more organized. L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make a list of the things you need to do, OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty nods her head, and Paul grabs a legal pad from his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. and MRS. ANDERSON, over-eager parents, sit across the desk from Letty, who stares at the legal pad in her lap. the Andersons talk, Letty twists a lock of hair tighter a tighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So at home, we've started our own little library for Chandra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought it would be a good project for her to set up her own card-catalogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty tries unsuccessfully to extricate her hand from her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what I'm wondering is whether we should also be spending more time on her computer skills at home. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we don't want her to get behind her classmates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we trust your opinion. Chandra's always talking about Miss Mayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the other day she came home and told us about you taking care of her bloody nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she went on and on about the collage. That seems very inventive, Miss Mayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stares blankly at the couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck. It's my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Mr. Anderson's raised eyebrow, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is a mess of scattered papers and the math Twist game. Letty sits on the ground crying. She makes a pyrami out of the wadded-up tissues that surround her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The upscale shop is festooned with pastels and lace and l of signs announcing "Sale Day." Frenzied women pick throu dresses as "Pachelbel's Canon" plays in the background. Letty is wedged into a corner, sipping coffee. A CLERK approaches her with a coffee pot and tray of pastries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rooting through the tray) No more bear claws left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth bounces into the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruth) Danish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no thanks, I'm too excited to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk gives Ruth an approving smile as Letty rips int sweet roll. Ruth looks through a nearby rack of gowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Letty) Where's Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to call her Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the old bag I sometimes call Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said she'd be here at 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth pulls a dress from the rack and holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have to see it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth looks closer at Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been crying?    Your eyes are all puffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty self-consciously touches her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things have been kind of stressful lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But everything's OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth is trying on a veil at this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, everything's under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the engagement party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's ready for tomorrow night--except the artillery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks so much for planning it, Letty. Jake's really looking forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty sighs, moves to the racks and pulls out a dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better start trying on before the vultures get all the good ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth twirls around in a taffeta gown as Letty picks up discarded dresses from the floor and hangs them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about this one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sisterly pride) You look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha Mayer is led in by the clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mom, I think I've found the dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look just wonderful, Ruthie. But I really think you should try on a few more, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty and Ruth shoot each other a look of doom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedraggled Letty and her mother fight the crowds to loo dresses. They are bumped and jostled from all sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Paul heard about his promotion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not yet. But you know Paul. He's sure to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth comes out of the dressing room in another gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the bias cut on that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mayer holds up an ornate dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more. I can't stand to try on one more dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty, I think this would be beautiful on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul could pop the question at any time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially with a promotion in the offing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Letty. I want to see it on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruth) Do you think I should?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.    It'll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty takes the gown and disappears into the dressing roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty emerges from the dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom?   Mom? Ruth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty peers around the corner, becoming a tad frantic. Bu neither her mother nor Ruth is to be found. It's just Let resplendent in ecru satin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they went over to the next shop to take a peek at shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pushes back her veil, sits down on the floor and ta a sip of her now-cold coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "House and Garden" picture of elegance. Letty, Paul, Ru and Jake stand at nervous attention, decked out in their Sunday best. A KNOCK marks the first arrival. Letty opens the door to mother, who does a quick reconnaissance of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather he's late as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her mother) Can I get you a glass of champagne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell RINGS. Letty greets her father, a mid 50s business type, and his wife MONICA, a younger version of Letty's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad, Monica.   I'm so glad you could come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the parents are face-to-face, Letty standing between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, this is Monica.   Monica, my mother, Martha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Mrs. Mayers make appropriate MURMURS. Letty's parents stare each other down. Ruth shifts from foot to f Silence falls in the room with a thump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, Mother, you've met before, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth takes a dramatic gulp of air. The evening hangs in t balance. Finally,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How've you been, Martha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Mayer and Monica cozy up to each other on the love se while Mrs. Mayer, Ruth and Paul sit on the opposite couch Letty passes hors d'oeuvres, and Jake doles out napkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mushroom-time, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (biting into one) I like the touch of cilantro. It is cilantro, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can always call it, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must get your cooking skills from your father, Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncomfortable silence falls on the party. Monica wipes th edge of Mr. Mayer's mouth with her napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth's narrowed the dress hunt down to two, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One's a silk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in front of Jake, Ruthie.    It's bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth looks at Letty nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember how hard it was looking for my dress. I must have been to 100 stores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mayer clears her throat.    More silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I think we need? Martinis. How about martinis to celebrate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puglia olives. Would I forget? (beat) A round of martinis coming right up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty leaves with Paul hot on her heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty shakes the martinis while Paul gets out the glasses Ruth enters the kitchen and sidles up to Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, can you hand me the olives? Ruth, I need you to, what was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the souffle?    Has that gone in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just put it in. But the squab, I think that needs to be basted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul hands Letty the olive bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ruth) Kind of icy in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Paul) Thank God we have alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty skewers olives and puts them in the martinis. Bits fleck rise from the olives, then swim to the tops of the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty grabs the olive bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stands still, fixated on the olive bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let?       L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olives Aux Herbes De Provence.    I got the wrong kind of olives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth holds up a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all the dreck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sage, rosemary... (in a sarcastic French accent) Les Herbes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. They've got to be Puglia olives, packed in a light brine with a flavor that doesn't overpower the palate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake enters.   The three turn on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave them alone./Get back in there./Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake whirls around and exits. Letty looks for olives, banging open the cupboards one af the other. Quicker and quicker. More and more frantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, Mr. Mayer, Monica and Mrs. Mayer stare at each othe listening with alarm to the wild slamming of cupboards in kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of those Lakers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty paws through her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wild-eyed) Can you loan me a 20?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're overreacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty turns her best school marm look on Paul. He hands o a crisp bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty, dinner's almost ready.   The souffle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back before you can say souffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty leaves from the kitchen's back door. Ruth heads to living room. Paul leans wearily against the counter, savoring one of the herb-filled martinis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fluorescent lights beat down on Letty. She races through aisles. She clutches her keys in one hand, a $20 bill in other. Letty careens around a corner. At the last second, she avoids smacking into another shopper. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelf after shelf of olives...black olives...all black.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Letty darts up and down the aisle, searching, searching. Nothing. Letty scurries to the front of the store. She taps a STOR CLERK on the shoulder. Six people waiting in line mutter, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find martini olives.     All you have are black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Aisle 2A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty whips down an aisle.    She starts to sweat. An OLD LADY blocks her path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss. I can't reach the cat food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pauses.    She reaches up and hands the woman a can food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a turkey and giblets, too, please. She does like her turkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty grabs another can, throws it in the Old Lady's cart darts away while the Old Lady continues to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign for Aisle 2A.    Olives.   Lots of them.   Green shapes. All sizes.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Letty's shoulders relax.    She scans the shelf. LETTY's POV: Labels of olives: big, small, with pimentos, without. from Puglia, Italy.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Letty zooms back to the front of the store.      To the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not there. I need the ones from Puglia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets no response from the clerk, who counts change fo customer. Letty gestures wildly with her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're the ones that are packed in brine, but they don't overpower the, you know, the palate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Specialty foods. 7B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty's off again. To the land of pink peppercorns, dehydrated mushrooms and Chinese 5-Spice. But no olives. Not a single bottle. Letty paws through the shelves, knocking things over as s scours the aisle. She is oblivious to the mess that surrounds her. An EMPLOYEE with a price checker walks half-way down the aisle. He spots Letty and rushes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?   Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More and more items crash to the ground.   Letty is beyon frenzied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manager to 7B. Manager please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pounds her fist against the shelf. More goods fall. Shoppers stare. The Manager rushes toward Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me where they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures. She knocks over a bottle of fat-free Lingonberry preserves. It crashes to the floor, spewing j

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need my olives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manager places his hand on the small of Letty's back if to guide her out of the store. Letty backs away. The manager grabs hold of her wrist. Letty whacks him in the shoulder with her free hand. She pushes him away. Hard. He staggers against the opposite shelf. Customers and employees gather at both ends of the aisle, riveted by the spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call security. Where's security, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty takes her arm and slides a shelf-full of products o the floor. They crash and break. She screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking olives. Fucking, fucking olives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two SECURITY GUARDS turn the corner.   Letty spots them. creeps closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guard One continues to approach, cooing encouragingly. Le throws a jar at him. It clips him in the head. He turns away, bleeding. Guard Two pulls out a billy club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Call police. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stops. Dazed. She turns around. Guard Two walks tow her. His stance suggests he's stalking a wild animal. Letty tries to brush off the jam that dribbles down her skirt. She looks to both ends of the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faces, dozens and dozens of faces, stare down at her.   P point. One boy LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Letty backs against the shelf. She slides down it until s is sitting on the floor. She buries her head in her knees sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is furnished like a Hyatt Hotel minus anything y might use to kill yourself. Letty sleeps. MICHAEL, mid 30's, in jeans and T-shirt, sits in a chair to the bed. He looks intently at Letty, checks his watch taps her on the shoulder. She stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayer? Miss Mayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's a morning blur. Gradually, items come into focus -- the intercom for the nurse, the door with a wind in it, the three tissue boxes on the bedside table. It's hospital, all right. Letty's vision is filled suddenly by Michael's concerned face peering into hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you've had a rough night, but I have a few questions for you, Miss Mayer, or Letitia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pulls herself up to a sitting position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I call you Letitia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting his notes) First off, Letty, can you tell me where you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I answered these questions last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this can be a real drag, but the attending physician on day shift is required to do his own prelim exam when a patient is admitted during the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hillview Psychiatric Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Now, Letty, I'd like you to remember three items. I'm going to ask you to repeat them in just a few minutes. They are chair, cup and ball. Did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, let's subtract 6 from a succession of numbers starting with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And 85 minus 6?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, 79. Sorry, this makes me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK. It's not a pass-fail kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty smiles uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the three things I asked you to remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chair, cup and ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty smiles, a real smile this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me shift gears here a minute... (beat) Do you ever hear voices that other people don't hear or see things they don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about patterns? Do you find yourself checking and re-checking locks? Or washing your hands over and over again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty shakes her head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about arranging your possessions in a certain way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?   Go right ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes my food, and my clothes, and my underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael leans closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you sort it--by lace and cotton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it's got a pattern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this really important? Because I don't think it's a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (looking at his notes) How long has it been since you've done something you've enjoyed, Letty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) A while, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be really difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty tears up.   Michael puts his hand lightly on her ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it'll be OK.   We'll make sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty gives him an appreciative look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now, why don't you just take it easy while I confer with my colleagues. A nurse should be in shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty, dressed and made up, sits rigidly on the bed. She writes in her organizer. DR. ROBERT EMLEE, early 40s and jeans, enters with his own organizer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Letitia. I'm Dr. Emlee, and I have some questions to ask you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did this already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hospital policy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be interviewed every hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the only doctor making rounds this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't have hallucinations. Honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doctor, was he tall, with dark hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and a dimple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Emlee shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Lhe's not a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychologist, therapist, whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, the man who came to see you, is a patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of place is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for the inconvenience, but I must ask you some...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see my mother immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We discourage family visits for the first 48 hours after an emotional trauma like the kind you've experienced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand.    I won't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to. Your family agreed to the conditions not to see you when they admitted you to Hillview, Letitia. (beat) We can talk about how that makes you feel, but we can't change the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty sinks back on her pillows, the wind knocked out of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Stone's evaluation from last night indicates you're experiencing a great deal of anxiety, probably related to depression...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Emlee continues to talk. His words become more and mo distant as the RINGING in Letty's head grows louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk about starting you on drug therapy. Most depressive personalities benefit from a drug like Prozac or maybe Zoloft...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bigger version of a waiting room you'd find in a doctor's office. And it has more games. Some patients watch television. Others play pool. Several form a group around Michael, who holds the same notebook used in his session with Letty. JOHN, unkempt in a bathro hands him a few ratty dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in for 5 for manic depressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMAS, late 40s and in a suit, waves a $5 bill at Michae

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with that as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael takes the money, and turns to MARIE, late 30s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to John and Thomas) You two always bet manic depressive. (to Michael) Tell me more about the guard she strangled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just hit in the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about voices?    Does she hear voices?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that she admits to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she a washer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but she is exceptionally organized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How organized?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She arranges her underwear by color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael motions to MRS. HALLSTROM, mid 50s, who shuffles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hallstrom, you want in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All tapped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll float you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hallstrom keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Michael) It's been weeks since she played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, Marie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Michael a $20 bill) I'll say major depression complicated by obsessive compulsive disorder. (beat) And could I get my change in ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty lags behind NURSE GATES, early 30s and in civilian clothes, as they walk down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treatment schedules are posted on the bulletin board. Dinner at 6, lights out at 10 and no fraternizing between patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing as she goes) That's the rec room. We show movies there on Wednesdays and Fridays...And this is the dining hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stops in her tracks at the sight of the room, an upscale version of a college cafeteria. Groups of people and talk. A paper airplane sails from one table to anothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really not that hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just eat whatever you want. This will give you a chance to meet some people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, my mom's coming to get me tomorrow. I'll be leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK, Letty. I'll be right here with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Gates guides Letty to a table where John, Mrs. Hallstrom, Marie and Thomas sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I said to my publisher this afternoon, I said, don't you even--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Hi, gang. I want to introduce you to Letty. (to Letty) Letty, this is Mrs. Hallstrom and Marie, and John and Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Letty) Just discussing my pesky publisher. May I ask what you do when you're not vacationing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Thomas) Let the poor girl get some food, for Heaven's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you may have gathered, I'm a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John snorts. Thomas ignores him.   Mrs. Hallstrom stares at her plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to say novelist. That sounds a little grandiose, but I am on my third novel and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me for interrupting, Thomas, but we really should get some food...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Gates leads Letty to a table, and hands her a plate Letty looks up to see Michael at the other end of the tab doing a card trick for two OTHER PATIENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to patients) Now I'm going to say that the card you picked was the Ace of Spades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips the top card up and it's the Ace of Spades. patients chortle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael turns toward the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, this is Letty.      She just arrived yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stares at Michael coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've met. (to Michael) I missed you during rounds this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty turns and leaves, carrying her empty plate with her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Michael) This doctor thing has got to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurses Gates hurries after Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stands outside the waiting room door. She tucks her blouse into her jeans and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty's mother sits on the edge of a couch in a room that looks much like the library of an English country manor. springs up as soon as she spots Letty. They rush to each other. Letty's mother strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, Sweetheart. I'm here. It's going to be OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Letty, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, I was there, and I just, I was so... They didn't have the olives, and I, I got so upset. I don't know how it happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've talked to Doctor Emlee, and he says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad to see you. You can't believe the people in here. They've got patients posing as doctors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone says it's the best facility in the area for this sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to go home.   Can we go home now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the best thing for you right now is to stay here and get well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should talk about this with Ruth, or Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all agree with the doctor, Dear. He thinks it's safer for you to stay here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty listens, waits, can't absorb it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all really think I need to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about Beast?   Who'll...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruth's already taken him home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my class. It'll be hard to find a good substitute. And what about my math program?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul said he'd call the school. (beat) And your father thinks he's convinced the guard not to press charges as long as you get help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For his injuries. I guess you...I guess he got hit in the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mayer holds out a duffel bag to Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I packed up some of your clothes, and I can bring whatever else you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty refuses to accept the duffel bag. Her mother sets i on the floor and stands. Letty is five again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, no, please don't go.    Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty's mother holds her. Mrs. Mayer, crying, pulls away from Letty. She kisses her daughter on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as Dr. Emlee says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty's mother walks out the door.    Letty stares after

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty, crying, unpacks her duffel bag, laboriously smooth and refolding every item she puts in the drawer. Finishing her task, Letty goes to the mirror and stares a her reflection. Finally, she fixes her makeup. Letty leaves her room. We follow her FOOTSTEPS down the hallway. In the distance, Letty sees the Rec Room. She hears the CLAMOR of voices. Every step is agony. Letty stops herself just before entering, trying to colle herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four people bet OCD and clinical depression so I split the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, her diagnosis was no mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially the OCD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick realization spreads over Letty's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, I mean, anyone who color- codes her panties has big problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty freezes. Michael rounds the corner. He stops when h sees her, falters, recovers his composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there. They're showing "Groundhog Day" if you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took bets on my diagnosis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no big deal.   We all compare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice rising) Who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patients are grouped in front of the TV, watching Bill Murray. Heads turn as they hear shouting in the hallway. Not even a moment's hesitation before, one by one, they g up and hurry to the hall. Only Mrs. Hallstrom remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, Marie and others gather around the fighters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no right, no right to take the worst thing that's ever happened to me and make it into some kind of game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop acting like you're someone special. You're just like the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the one who's masquerading as a doctor. I'm not the one who's, who's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Letty) He's schizophrenic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the one who's schizophrenic. I don't see people who aren't there or run around acting crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pounds her fist against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Girl!/ Come on, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, you're perfectly sane. That's why you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty looks like she's been slapped. She thinks for a moment. The patients wait, breathless, for her retort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael grins at Letty. She turns, and strides down the hall. There's a smattering of applause. It grows stronger We see Letty's eyes fill with tears as, behind her, the patients yell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo./Encore./Re-match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty, unable to sleep, tosses and turns. She gets out of bed and paces the room nervously, trying to hold herself together. She slumps to the floor and starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Emlee and seven patients sit in a circle of metal fol chairs. Michael, who sits next to Emlee, practices rollin quarter back and forth across his fingers. Letty sits across from Michael and Emlee, her legs and ar crossed tightly. The group concentrates on Mrs. Hallstrom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stop thinking about the things I did wrong when my daughter was little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how's that make you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel like sleeping.    All the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell's bells, you can count me in on that. I haven't had enough Z's since I ran those sleep disorder experiments at Stanford back in the 70s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We really miss doing things with you, Mrs. Hallstrom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, sitting next to Mrs. Hallstrom, squeezes her arm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe when I hit my manic phase again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group members smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've noticed Letty doesn't much like to do things with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group looks expectantly at Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Of course I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you so defensive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to John) I don't think we need to sacrifice Letty to pep up a slow session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Michael) You're the one who told everyone about her panties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael grimaces at John.   Letty's head is bent down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd like to share some of your feelings about OCD or depression with us, Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty eyes the doctor.   She's dangerously close to tears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have to talk about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think in the spirit of group therapy, it's beneficial for each of us to open ourselves up to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael reaches his hand behind Dr. Emlee's head, catchin Letty's eye in the process. Michael pulls a silver dollar of Emlee's ear. Letty looks but doesn't respond. The other patients ignor Michael. Emlee is oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know, Letty, how the person sitting next to you may be able to shed light on one of your problems...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael goes for a bigger trick. Reaching again behind th doctor's head, he produces a small bouquet of paper flowe Letty, almost against her will, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...by revealing something that's going on in his or her own life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael waves the flowers back and forth behind the docto head. Letty's smile broadens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (responding to her smile) There, now, I knew you'd feel better once we discussed group process. Let's talk a little about your OCD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty ponders a shelf of ratty paperbacks. Michael turns corner, thumbing through a dog-eared book. Letty spots hi and moves away. Michael sidles up next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for a romance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking to read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael holds out his book to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty glances at the title, "101 MAGIC TRICKS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're checking it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already checked it out 17 times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael reaches behind Letty. She pulls away. He produces scarf from behind her back, and presents it to her. She doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep the book.   I'm looking for Emily Dickinson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty walks away.   Michael follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if you take the magic book, I'll feel like maybe you accept my apology and don't hate me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't heard an apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael drops to one knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry I hurt your feelings. I got a little carried away. Can you ever forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty takes the book from him and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty sits in an arm chair staring out at the garden. Her attention is drawn to a nearby couch where Michael sits opposite Mrs. Hallstrom, apparently playing cards. Michael lays a card down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hallstrom, I'm pretty sure you could use that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head slowly back and forth.   Michael plac in her hand of cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, don't you have a gin rummy, Mrs. Hallstrom? (beat) Go ahead, now, just lay those cards down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hallstrom slowly spreads her hand of cards on the co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot damn. Gin rummy. I told you so. You're three games up on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hallstrom smiles. Michael catches Letty watching the and Letty quickly looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty opens her drawer to pull out a T-shirt. Several are rumpled. She starts refolding them when she spots it. There, nestled among her clothes, is a book of Emily Dickinson's poetry. Letty picks it up, runs her hand over the cover and starts reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Letty walk onto a postcard-perfect stone terrace overlooking the garden. Paul pulls up a chair for Letty a stares out at the scenery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's prettier here than I thought it would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a big question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it wasn't something I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something you did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That put you in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, no. (beat) Is that why you're here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we need to talk about some things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been really difficult, this whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL(cont'd) These past few weeks, it's made me really go back and examine our whole relationship. (beat) I mean, we've been going out for four years, and it hasn't always been so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially this last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Especially now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I've been thinking a lot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have too, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to Ruth a little bit, and I think it's about time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. We can't just keep going through the motions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. It's time to make decisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to say anything else. I've known for a while that this was coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wish we'd done it sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul takes Letty's hand in his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul pulls a diamond ring from his pocket and puts it on Letty's finger. She stares at it, mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to smuggle it in here. I guess you're not really supposed to have jewelry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by rote) Or be up past ten or fraternize with other patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you like it. It's a Marquis cut, 1.5 carats. They had one with emeralds around it, but this was simpler, more classic in its lines. (beat) Letty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's, it's really nice, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can take it back and we can have one custom made if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you've done a perfect job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do you say, Let?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty looks him in the eyes for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think, really, that it's OK to get engaged when I'm in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. We'll save the formal announcement for when you're out. I already told your mother. I hope you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working up a smile) Of course. Yes. I will.     I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Letty kiss, then hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's completely dark. Letty sits in the same position we her in hours ago. Michael walks up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed out on some great broccoli florets at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John even managed to lob a load of mashed potatoes into Mrs. Hallstrom's milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Finally. I was getting tired of watching him try every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it bad news--the visit from Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looked pretty serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very romantic setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was romantic.   He's very romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you engaged, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty holds out her hand, where the diamond glistens. Mic bends forward to look at the ring, caressing her hand as does so. Letty pulls away. The ring is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done with the ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't funny.   Paul would kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael holds his hands in fists toward Letty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess which hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough with the abracadabra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The left one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael opens his hand.   It's empty.   Michael addresses imaginary audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to audience) The fair maiden guesses incorrectly. Should we give her one more try? (to Letty) The audience says one more try. What guess you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael opens his right hand. A plastic, Cracker-jack rin rests in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael grabs Letty's hand and slides the ring onto her finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this ring, I thee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty pulls her hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, this isn't funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, OK, I'll give it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't do your portion of kitchen cleanup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm not covering for you when you sneak out to call Dominos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty stares at him.    She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael moves close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty looks into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Everything's a joke with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Letty kiss, long and deep. Letty pulls back. She gazes at Michael. She steps closer to him. They kiss again, longer and deeper. They separate. Letty looks ready for another kiss.   Mich caresses her cheek. He walks back toward the hospital door. He stops, comes b to Letty. He hands her the diamond ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks inside.   Letty watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Emlee and Letty sit across from each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The medicine's still bothering me. It feels like I have cotton wrapped around my brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see about adjusting the dosage if that doesn't clear in the next (week. (beat) How are other things going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've told you all the news. Let's see--the engagement. Oh, and my sister's coming to visit me, and they say my cat misses me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question, Letty, is how are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss Beast a lot, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Michael sleeps. A Christmas Carol BLASTS throug the intercom system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hark the Herald Angels sing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael bolts awake. He stumbles out of bed, in wildly striped boxers, and races toward the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors open like kernels of popcorn exploding.   Michael, Marie, Thomas, John, then Letty. The music BLARES on. Nurse Gates runs down the hall and shouts to Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music lowers. Mrs. Hallstrom, in a Santa cap, appears She distributes erasers as she threads through the patien

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry. Candy canes are out of season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hallstrom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hallstrom gives an eraser to the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Come with me, Mrs. Hallstrom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Gates leads Mrs. Hallstrom away as the older woman continues tossing erasers down the hall. Marie stares at Michael's shorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot boxers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael smiles awkwardly at Letty. She returns to her roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letty climbs into bed. She opens the bedside drawer, and pulls out a Tiffany's ring box. There, cradled in the sat lining, is the diamond from Paul. Right beside it is Michael's Cracker Jack special. Letty puts on Paul's ring. She studies her hand. With an of secrecy, she slips on Michael's ring. She quickly take it off. Wearing Paul's ring, she turns off the light and snuggles into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon light casts long shadows in the garden of prune hedges and tea roses. Letty and Ruth power-walk down a cobblestone path, heading away from the English Tudor hospital that looms large in the background. Letty wears a sweatshirt emblazoned with the logo for the University of South Carolina Cocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you finally gave me the shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loaned you. And it's only 'til you get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That settles it. I'm never leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hardly wait 'til you're free. Planning the wedding without you has been a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're slowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
